"Gurira's writing contains flashes of sly, gentle humor, but for the most part this is very tough medicine â€” a story of how western African women's choices all often lead to the same dead ends. That the play never turns suffocatingly grim is a testament to the warmth and humanity of the actresses, who are at their finest during the show's quietest moments, braiding one another's hair, or reading aloud from a beaten-up copy of Bill Clinton's autobiography that they stumble upon."
